response.answer_text: Politically, most of them aren’t for religious rule. Ideologically, some may differ from others. The Egyptian presidential election, 2012 saw the rise of Islamists to power because the other option was a way-back portal to the Mubarak era, though he was secular and suffered a very close defeat by the Islamist Muslim Brotherhood. The MB had been outlawed for years until Mubarak resigned in 2011, because they introduced religious extremism to Egypt in 1928. Whenever somebody asks me if Egypt is inherently religious, I always like to reference a speech given by Gamal Abd-El Nasser, Egypt’s 2nd president. In it, he mentioned a Muslim Brotherhood figure's demands which included that women should wear the headscarf more often in public, a man stood up and yelled “let him wear it himself!” This was the popular sentiment in Egypt in the 20th century, after British rule was abolished and Egypt’s ruling class was almost crushed. Religion has historically been a spiritual affair in Egypt, whether it’s Christianity or Islam. Perhaps nationalism was the more destructive sentiment because it drove us into many wars, but it was never “jihad” or “holy war” (note: that’s actually true of most if not all Arab Muslim-majority countries that are secular by nature). I don’t see religion everywhere I go. There are almost no religious “laws” (except for family laws and laws against adultery/infidelity which exist everywhere in the world). There are religious establishments like Dar Al Ifta’a and Al-Azhar which play a prominent role in organizing Islam and keeping it separate from the state. Similarly, Coptic Christians have the Patriarch of Alexandria. We have churches, mosques, religious festivals, and yes the majority of us are Muslim, but we survive on a live-and-let-live tolerance. The majority of women wear headscarves, some wear the niqab, religion is perfectly in tact, but we keep it between ourselves (perhaps that’s a very lazy generalization on my part). The far-right isn’t at all powerful in Egypt, it’s replaced by socialist and nationalist parties. We’ve only ever had one Islamist president and his rule didn’t last a full year. Islamists pursue a majoritarian form of government and that just doesn’t fly with Egyptians. The legal framework takes elements of the Islamic shari’a but doesn’t incorporate it in its fullest because we have the largest Coptic community in the world. Nowhere in the Arab world do people live, eat, and sleep by religious standards. None of us are ideal Muslims, Christians, or Jews (yup). Religion is an integral part of our identity but it doesn’t overtake our sense of loyalty to our countries, which involves religious tolerance. This is insulting by many people’s standards. I’d be lying if I said we had no religious extremists (Muslim Brotherhood supporters et al), but I don’t think Egyptians in particular fit the term “religious.”
